I’ll be looking at the moon,

1119972579819827201.text: So many replies to this saying, “but I don’t have a choice!” Yeah, I’m saying that’s a bad thing; whoever is setting your workload is doing it wrong. We shouldn’t shy away from talking about the ways in which people are being used badly — whether or not they’re the ones deciding.https://twitter.com/AstroKatie/status/1119729970262224896 …

1119805823625170944.text: There’s tons of research out there that shows that on average, productivity drops dramatically when people are overworked. For most people, after ~40 hours, you’re not doing good work. Here’s a summary: https://cs.stanford.edu/people/eroberts/cs181/projects/crunchmode/econ-hours-productivity.html … Whoever sets workloads should take this into account.

1119729970262224896.text: If you’re an academic habitually working much more than 40 hours/week, you’re probably producing less good work than if you reduced your hours. If you absolutely CAN’T manage within a reasonable schedule, you’re probably doing a lot of things that don’t advance your field/career.

1116058936610906114.text: When Einstein was working on general relativity, he realized he needed more sophisticated math than he knew, so he had his colleague Marcel Grossmann teach him differential geometry. Science is a collaborative venture! More on the "lone genius" idea here: http://astrokatie.blogspot.com/2013/06/the-lone-genius-hypothesis.html …

1116058935205736448.text: I get that people like to have an archetypical extreme genius, and Einstein did accomplish a lot! But he didn't discover EVERYTHING and he certainly didn't work alone. He had lots of collaborators and built his ideas on a LOT of previous work.

1116053661015269377.text: Everything we've seen about #BlackHoles fits with Einstein's theory of gravity, general relativity. But PLEASE don't give Einstein credit for coming up with black holes -- when they were theorized by others, he didn't even believe they could happen!https://twitter.com/coreyspowell/status/1116052491572060161 …

1116037856252911617.text: The idea that anything in science has been "proven" is a tricky one; most of the time, you just pile up evidence beyond all reasonable doubt. I would say that we've been in that situation with black holes for a long time. But, still, *seeing* one swallow up light? EXTREMELY COOL

1116037102184140806.text: The unique thing about the @ehtelescope #BlackHoleImage is that it's showing us something we haven't seen before: the dark region of space where light has been pulled in & swallowed up. If it were just a massive star or solid object, the center of the image would be bright.pic.twitter.com/fIKibfOxj5

1116035972410609666.text: There's been a LOT of great evidence for #BlackHoles in the cosmos. @LIGO #GravitationalWave detections have shown us how they warp & shake up space itself! We've seen extremely small bright sources -- apparently hot matter being pulled in, & sometimes stars being ripped apart!

1116034929874415617.text:
Q: Does the #EHT #BlackHoleImage result finally prove the existence of black holes?

1115983437234622469.text: A sense of scale: the #BlackHole seen here is 6.5 billion times the mass of the Sun, but 55 million light years away. So the image is tiny: the “shadow” seen here is about 40 micro-arcseconds across from this vantage point; a full moon looks tens of millions of times larger.

1115974725413625856.text: With this image & associated data, we can learn about the nature of the giant black holes at the centers of galaxies. So far, looking at this one, we can say that it’s NOT a wormhole or a boson star, but other alternative hypotheses need more data to be ruled out. #EHT #BlackHole

1115580268033839105.text: A black hole “shadow” isn’t a shadow at all, of course. It’s a part of space that’s so warped that it’s pulling all the light into it, so even though there’s extraordinarily bright glowing plasma all around it, in that small region all you can see is pure black.

1115578560465506305.text: We already take pics of black holes; what’s @ehtelescope looking for? Usually, we see a bright glow from the whirlpool of matter falling in (the accretion disk). EHT might be able to make out the “shadow”: a dark hole in that glow from where light can’t escape the event horizon.

1115575585030516739.text: A reminder, while we’re on the subject, that black holes (or, to be precise, the stuff in their VERY near vicinity) are actually some of the brightest things in the cosmos:https://cosmosmagazine.com/space/the-bright-side-of-black-holes …

1112769846570352642.text: (If you’re wondering which part of this I learned today, it was the part about how almost none of what’s made in the core of a massive star survives. I’d thought some of it would.)

1112768588031684608.text: There’s more info on all this on @jajohnson51’s page here: http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/%7Ejaj/nucleo/index.html …

1112767975948513281.text: There are other processes that make heavy elements, like death throes of lower-mass stars, and neutron star collisions (!!), but the steady burning inside high-mass stars gets kind of exploded over and doesn’t account for much in the end.

1112767140044722179.text: When the core turns into iron & the nuclear burning stops working, the star collapses, & the shockwave that tears through it quickly burns up everything the star just spent all that time creating through normal fusion, & THAT’S where the heavy elements that get out come from.

1112766424332845058.text: Anyway, here: You know how massive stars can make oxygen, carbon, etc, in their cores? (Short version: our Sun does hydrogen->helium but heavy stars can go up to iron.) Pretty much none of what gets out, and later becomes planets & us, comes from that.

1103280047899754497.text: If someone talks to you about “frequencies” without specifying what it is that’s repeating, it’s probably nonsense. Ask: is this a kind of radiation you’re referring to? Is it electromagnetic radiation? How is it measured? How is it emitted? “Frequencies” don’t exist alone. (2/2)

1103280047018950656.text: Quick jargon lesson: “frequency” means the number of times something happens in a certain unit of time. A bus route might have a frequency of two buses per hour, for instance, or a sound wave 500 Hz (which means 500 waves per second), or a radio wave 500 kHz (500,000 Hz). (1/2)

1102173680845705216.text: To emphasize how cool this is: we are starting with tiny tiny variations in microwave light that comes to us from when the cosmos was still basically ON FIRE from the Big Bang and we use some math and out comes THE DISTRIBUTION OF ACTUAL GALAXIES IN SPACE

1102170461562175489.text:
How cosmic simulations are done:
1) Write code to simulate mass & gravity for little bits of dark matter
2) Set up their distribution based on tiny fluctuations we see in THE LITERAL AFTERGLOW OF THE BIG BANG
3) Let code run for a while & it looks like what we see in the sky

1093695340136546305.text: The population density of Japan is similar to that of the Boston-Washington Corridor. In Europe, smaller pop densities and larger distances also work for high speed trains. There are obstacles to better networks here, but they’re not invincible and they’re well worth fighting.

1093686545905799170.text: The Shinkansen network has expanded, of course. It now has lines that cover something close to 3,000 km, and it moves around 160 million people a year. At up to 320 km/hr. No seatbelt light. No turbulence. Stations right in city centers. Just imagine what travel could be here.

1093684745081368577.text: One of the proposals in the “Green New Deal” is to build high-speed train lines so flying is less necessary. This is not a radical proposal. In Japan, the Shinkansen covers distance approx LA-San Francisco in 2.5 hrs. At peak, trains every 10 minutes. The line was built in 1964.

1093181451032502272.text:
Q: I thought you'd talk about how science has a massive return on investment, & creates technology that improves lives & stuff.

A: All that is true! But let's not place zero value on curiosity, discovery, & things that make humans feel like we've accomplished something awesome.

1093181450390855680.text:
Q: Don't we study basic science for the technology spin-offs and improvements to medical technology and stuff?

A: Sure. Yes. All those things. Also: because it's cool. I mean, look, it's the Universe! It's amazing! Mysterious! Where we come from! Humans LOVE that sort of thing.

1093181449551970304.text:
Q: Why should we invest in basic science like understanding the Big Bang and all that?

A: There are lots of reasons! But fundamentally? It turns out understanding the world/Universe around us is just A Thing Humans Like.

And now I've just seen an article in @EpochTimes, reposted in @news_ntd, that basically just cribs from the @washingtonpost piece and claims that I "suggested it was all a publicity stunt in bad faith," which is equally wrong/libelous.

Sometimes I hate the new media landscape.

1092849697541234688.text: Several people have commented to me that they saw my "quote" and thought it was very uncharacteristic language for me to use. I'm sure many many more just read the story and accepted it.

1092593510480560128.text: Anyway, if you see an article claiming that I suggested another astrophysicist was "trolling for publicity," please ignore it. The claim is completely false, presumably intended to stir up trouble, at the expense of myself, my colleague, and the readers.

1092589322937778176.text: I won't link to the article. But in general, if you see an article quoting someone as having told a different outlet something, it's a good idea to click through to the source of the quote and see what they actually said, and in what context.

Q: Is it OK to look at a #LunarEclipse with the naked eye?
A: Yes! Best way to see it. Look up & enjoy!

Q: How often do lunar eclipses happen?
A: Few times a year

Q: Will the #SuperBloodWolfMoon awaken warewolves/bring about the apocalypse?
A: The Moon claims no responsibility

1087193796532555776.text: Lately, it’s been fashionable to add extra names to each #LunarEclipse. This one gets “wolf” from “Wolf Moon,” an old-fashioned name for a January full moon, & “super” from the being Moon at its closest point in its orbit, so it looks (slightly) bigger. #SuperBloodWolfMoon

1087192592649879554.text: The red glowing Moon seen during a total #LunarEclipse is the reason for the (fairly recent) monicker “blood moon.” I guess it sounds catchy, and to be fair, it can look a bit gruesome. https://earthsky.org/human-world/what-is-a-blood-moon-lunar-eclipses-2014-2015 … (Image: http://www.MrEclipse.com )pic.twitter.com/XJpsrdMiES

1087191502298570754.text: During totality, when the whole Moon is in shadow, instead of it disappearing completely, it turns a deep red. This light is the red glow of all the world’s sunsets and sunrises — the only light reaching the Moon when it’s in shadow. From the Moon, the Earth looks ringed in fire.

1087190719264055298.text: When the Moon starts to enter the Earth’s shadow, it’ll look like part of the Moon is going dark, in contrast to the section just outside the shadow, still brightly lit. But when it’s ENTIRELY in the shadow, you’ll see something else, much cooler. #LunarEclipse

1087190111832293376.text: A total #LunarEclipse is when the Moon, Earth, and Sun line up perfectly enough that the Moon is entirely in the Earth’s shadow. Here’s a handy graphic:https://twitter.com/astrokatie/status/518697246305439745?s=21 …

1087189476995002368.text: If you can see the Moon tonight, over the next few hours it’s going to start looking pretty awesome. 1081387849050554368.text: When I was a high schooler, I was extremely fortunate to find a physics prof who let me come in and try my hand at some research stuff and it was AMAZINGLY valuable for me. But it takes having certain resources, time, and experience to be able to offer that, & not every prof does

1071406225340989442.text: Now that China’s Chang'e-4 is en route to the far side of the Moon, it’s a good time to remind everyone that the far side is NOT the “dark side.” The “dark side” is just whatever side is not currently being lit up by the Sun, which depends on the time of month, and varies.

1069632349355352064.text: The @OSIRISREx mission is cool for another reason: it’s a sample return mission. After orbiting for a while, in 2020 OSIRIS-REx will sidle up to #Bennu & PUNCH IT IN THE FACE. The little sample in the punching arm (“Touch-And-Go Sample Acquisition Mechanism”) will return in 2023.

1066543242240565250.text: “The First Cosmic Light and the Cocoon of Fire” — a short thread about light and deep time and perceptionhttps://twitter.com/i/moments/1066541259400114176 …

1066531993658249217.text: The most distant layer of time that we can see is the light that has been traveling since the moment the primordial fire began to cool. The cosmic microwave background surrounds us at every edge of our vision. We are embedded in shells of cosmic time, and the final one is fire.

1066531118957109248.text: We are not the center of the Universe. But we are the center of our own perception as light reaches us from afar; we lie embedded in nesting-doll layers of cosmic time. Each concentric sphere is an era. We can see the structure of matter changing, like geological strata around us

1066529593480368128.text: When we look at the most distant parts of the cosmos, in every direction, we see parts of the Universe that are so far in the past, they’re still in the final stages of the Big Bang. So far away, so far back, the space is filled with a dense, roiling plasma, the fire of creation.

1066528945175232512.text: We can see something even more distant, and more ancient, than the first galaxies. If we peer out far enough, in between the galaxies, we can see parts of the Universe that are so far away, it has taken the light from that distance almost the entire age of the cosmos to reach us.

1066528204695969793.text: With powerful telescopes, we can see galaxies whose light has been traveling to us for more than 13 billion years. We see them shining in a universe that’s still young, where gravity has just begun to pull matter together into stars and galaxies.

1066527654332063744.text: You can’t see the Sun as it is now, but you can see it as it was about 8 minutes ago. You can’t see Alpha Centauri now, but you can see it 4.4 years ago. You can see the Andromeda Galaxy as it was 2.5 million years in the past. And so on.

1066526665164103681.text: Hold your hand up 12 inches from your face: you’re seeing your hand as it was a nanosecond ago. Everything you look at is, to one degree or another, in the past. The farther away in space, the more ancient in time.

1066526148149108736.text: Light travels at about 1 foot per nanosecond.

1066032530049179648.text: The thing that kills you for VERY sure as soon as you pass the event horizon is that within the event horizon, it is NO LONGER POSSIBLE for anything, including your blood or nerve impulses, to travel a direction away from the singularity. This is not survivable. #BlackHoleFriday

1066032077454393350.text: If you make it all the way through the event horizon without being spaghettified (which is possible for very massive black holes), you’re... not in luck. You’re gonna die immediately. LONG before you’re crushed at the singularity. #BlackHoleFriday

1066031611014193153.text: There’s also the possibility of a firewall, which is a hypothetical surface of high energy radiation right at the black hole event horizon, but the jury is still out on that idea https://www.quantamagazine.org/black-hole-firewalls-confound-theoretical-physicists-20121221/ … #BlackHoleFriday

1066030631673651200.text: If your black hole doesn’t have a jet or an accretion disk, you’ll still have to deal with the extreme space curvature and tidal forces. This will mess you up—specifically, you’ll be spaghettified, which is what it sounds like. #BlackHoleFriday (image: NASA)pic.twitter.com/pCEyrc7I7T

1066029548331024385.text: First of all, approaching a black hole will usually involve tangling with its accretion disk: a whirlpool of matter falling in that gets hot enough to emit x-rays just from the friction. And in some cases, there’s a super high energy particle jet. Not fun! #BlackHoleFriday

1066028980233543680.text: My favorite thing about black holes at the moment is how really truly comprehensively they kill you if you try to enter. I mean, a black hole will kill you in SEVERAL different ways. #BlackHoleFriday

1066028323107676161.text: I highly recommend following #BlackHoleFriday today — lots of great black hole tweets by @NASA, @BadAstronomer, @bnprime, @chandraxray, @mcnees, and many others!

1065610018840559616.text: Nice reminder that the effects of a changing climate on small timescales or in small regions are not always the same as what you’d expect on a global scalehttps://twitter.com/rahmstorf/status/1065255559677599744 …

1065447523215704064.text: Anyway, to lose winter altogether, globally, we’d have to be in a kind of Venus situation, where the planet is being suffocated to death by its own atmosphere. We’re not there (yet)! Enjoy the snow while you can.

1065447520799739907.text: As the planet warms, your summers will get *on average* hotter because the fact that you’re exposed to more sun will be exacerbated by the extra blanketing of greenhouse gas, and your winters will *on average* get warmer too.

1065447518622965760.text: No matter what happens with the overall climate of the planet, you’ll still have local summers and winters, where it’ll be relatively hot or cold. Weather systems can get more extreme, in both directions, when the global climate gets messed up, though.

1065447514508324865.text: Seasons happen because during what you call winter, your half (north or south) of the Earth is tilted away from the Sun, and in summer, your half is tilted toward it. So you get more direct light and more hours of light as Earth rotates on its tilted axis in summer.pic.twitter.com/kMOWryOZLI
